page.title: 20Hill of Barra Bourtie
page.content:
The Pictish hillfort on Bourtie's Hill of Barra stands, at 635 feet, as a reminder of the Iron Age. Though covered in whin (gorse) which blooms bright yellow in April, farmers have a custom of burning down the gorse stems when they die back every three years. Flint arrowheads appear frequently from mouths of rabbit burrows on the hill, in ploughed fields at Redhouse and in the gardens of the Old Manse and Schoolhouse in Bourtie. Bourtie farmers reflect the Pictish calendar in customs, sayings and their use of quarter days (first of February, May, August, November). "In Candlemas by dull and cool Half the winter's over at Yule If Candlemas be bright and clear Half the winter's to come and mair"
Contributor: Pages 2-20 M Nagahiro
